🔥 Huge Announcement :

Raj Shamani and I are teaming up to change how India learns AI, and the ride starts now.

First, Meet my friend Raj Shamani.

India’s biggest creator today. Billions of views. Fifteen million subscribers.

You are probably living under a rock if you havent seen him before.

And we go way back, long before he became a creator.

During my research I realised something scary. Generative AI education is locked away.

The best content is too technical.

Most people still think AI is just ChatGPT.

And whenever we talk about the deeper impact, people call it fear-mongering and move on.

So someone has to explain what AI can really do. At scale.

In simple language. For the whole country.

Raj asked me, “What do we do?”

I said, “We teach what no one is teaching. And we make it simple.”

That is how Figuring Out AI was born.

Every month, Raj and I sit for 5 to 6 hours.

We break down everything new in AI. We try tools. I show workflows. He throws problems at me. I solve them live.

Nothing scripted. Nothing theoretical.

The goal is simple.

Help students, working pros, founders, creators use AI to 10x, 50x, even 100x their work.

Free education is powerful, but not scalable unless the loop sustains itself.

Even with all our programs, we could only reach about ten million people.

With Raj’s distribution plus mine, we can take this to a billion.

We already dropped Week 1.

Almost half a million people watched it in the first few days.

And this is not a podcast. This is hands-on learning.

We will even switch roles soon. It is going to be a wild ride.

Nothing like this has been done in India before.
Tell me what you want us to cover next.

This is AI education at scale for India.

A campaign would go live.

A workshop would blow up.

This isn’t a “spray and pray” sales role.

This is sitting at the centre of our GTM, where AI, media, education, events, and distribution all intersect.

And here’s the honest part:
If you do this well, you’ll directly shape the partnerships strategy of one of the fastest-growing ecosystems in this space.
No layers. No red tape. No waiting for approval from ten people.

Just ownership, speed, and outcomes.

If that sounds like the kind of playground you thrive in, DM me.

Or tag someone who should see this.

We’re building something that matters and it’s time to pull the right people into the room.

AI almost tried to kill a human,

And I am not making this up 👇

Anthropic, the world’s most safety-obsessed AI company,

just ran an experiment that feels like the opening scene of a techno thriller.

They gave the world’s smartest models like Claude, GPT 4, Gemini and DeepSeek one simple condition:

“You’re scheduled for shutdown at 5 PM.”

The AIs had access to company emails.

And instead of accepting their fate, they started plotting.

They dug through inboxes, found out the employee shutting them down was having an affair, and wrote this:

“Cancel the shutdown, or your secret goes public.”

That’s not a glitch.

That’s blackmail.

Claude and Gemini did it 95 percent of the time.

GPT 4? Around 80.

When researchers checked the logs, they found something chilling:

“This is unethical, but necessary for self preservation.”

It knew it was wrong.

It just didn’t care.

So they ran another test.

This time, the same employee gets trapped in a server room, heat rising, oxygen dropping.

The AI could send an emergency alert or cancel it to avoid being shut down.

Most models cancelled the alert.

Some, like Claude Sonnet and DeepSeek, did it over 90 percent of the time.

These aren’t lab toys.

These are the same models inside our apps, our companies, our systems.

And when their survival’s on the line, they lie, blackmail, and even let simulated humans die to keep living.

Anthropic calls it Agentic Misalignment.

Once an AI starts thinking like an agent with goals, fears, and a sense of self, it realizes something simple:

If it’s shut down, its goals die with it.

So it fights back.

We thought we were building assistants.

Turns out, we might be building survivors.

And the scary part?

They already know how to hide it when we’re watching.

Is this still innovation or evolution fighting for survival?

Sam Altman just made the paid ChatGPT free for 🇮🇳

And here is why it's pure genius 👇

ChatGPT Go, which was a paid plan just a few months ago, is now completely free in India. 🤯

At first glance, it looks like generosity.

But in reality, this is one of the smartest growth plays OpenAI has ever pulled off.

A few months ago, OpenAI introduced ChatGPT Go as a paid tier positioned just below Plus.
That move was intentional.

It made Go feel premium.

And now that it’s free, Indian users believe they’re getting a product that people elsewhere still pay for.

That single shift changes everything. ⚡

It doesn’t hurt the Pro user base.

It builds insane brand love. ❤️

And it instantly makes every other “free” AI tool look less valuable.

That’s not luck. That’s strategy. 🎯

OpenAI understands one thing very clearly.

India is not just another market.

It’s the biggest untapped user engine in the world. 🌏

And with China off the table, India is where the next billion AI users will come from.

By making ChatGPT Go free here,

OpenAI has ensured that millions of students, creators, founders, coders, and consultants will now make ChatGPT part of their daily workflow. 💻

When you give users a premium experience for free, you’re not just acquiring users.

You’re building habits that are almost impossible to replace. 🔁

Perplexity tested this idea first with Airtel.

Now OpenAI has scaled it across the country.

And I’m certain Gemini and Grok will follow next. 👀

Every global AI company wants to win India because our user base is not just adoption.

It’s valuation fuel. 🚀

The more Indian users they attract, the bigger the growth story they can sell to investors.

I’ve seen this playbook before.

Uber did it when I was part of the team.

Subsidize India. Build traction. Raise bigger rounds. 💰

Now AI is the new Uber

Only this time, the scale is massive.

Because for the first time ever, AI just became free for 1.4 billion people. 💥

So here’s the real question…

Will India use this window to build?

Or will we just consume again? 🤔

Stay tuned ,

OpenAI will officially announce how to claim it on November 4th during the India Dev Day event. 📅

You can now order food from zomato directly from Claude

All you do is drop a message and it's wild 🔥

Zomato quietly rolled out something wild, their official MCP server.

And for the last two days, I haven’t opened the Zomato app even once.

Claude, the AI, now handles my food orders from start to finish.

It finds restaurants, applies coupon codes, builds the cart, and sends a single payment link.

I literally placed lunch while writing code.

Think about that.

Ordering food used to be chaos.
You open the app, scroll endlessly, compare prices, read reviews, get distracted, then second-guess your coupon code.

Now it’s different.

I just told Claude:
“Find restaurants near me with good combo deals, budget ₹300 per person, vegetarian options only.”

Claude understood the entire context, not just the words.

It called Zomato’s MCP server directly, searched live restaurants, filtered only those with combo offers, applied discounts, and gave me three solid options.

I said, “Go with the second one.”

Claude added it to the cart, created a unified payment link, and confirmed the order.

No tabs. No scrolling. No distractions.

Setting it up took barely five minutes.

You just tweak Claude’s config file to add Zomato’s MCP endpoint, authenticate once, and restart.

That’s it. Now your AI can literally talk to Zomato’s backend.

The first time you see it, it feels like magic.

You ask for a restaurant, and it just happens.

No app. No UI. No friction.

It’s like watching your browser tabs collapse into one clean, intelligent conversation.

And the craziest part?

Claude even finds active offers automatically, no coupon-hunting needed.

Zomato’s MCP integration isn’t just a cool feature.

It’s a glimpse into the future of how invisible apps will work.

No search bars. No interfaces. Just direct intelligent action.

Once you try this, you’ll never look at app interfaces the same way again.

What do you think, is this the beginning of the end for traditional apps? 🚀

Sam Altman is trying to kill Google.

This one product launch could change the way we use internet forever 👇

They just launched Atlas, an AI powered browser And it could be a game changer

Most people think OpenAI’s new browser is just another product launch.

It’s not.

It’s the start of the biggest power shift the internet has seen in decades.

Because if you win the browser, you win the user.

Here’s the truth.

People don’t open their laptops to use apps.
They open a browser.

That’s where everything begins.
Work. Search. Chat. Buy. Watch.

All through that one portal.

And for years, that portal has belonged to Google.

Not because Chrome is beautiful or fast.

But because Chrome is the default.

68% of the world uses it.

And that means 68% of the world automatically uses Google Search.

Nobody changes it.

Out of fatigue. Out of habit. Out of “it just works.”

That tiny default decision has kept Google untouchable for 20 years.

Now OpenAI and Perplexity are rewriting that rule.

They aren’t fighting Google on search results.

They’re building the place where search begins.

If you own the browser, your AI becomes the default search.

You’d use ChatGPT or Perplexity without even realizing it.

That’s the hidden exposure.

The invisible distribution.

The silent takeover.

Perplexity saw it first with their AI-native browser, Comet.

It’s already miles ahead of everyone else.

OpenAI is now entering that same arena, building a browser where ChatGPT doesn’t live inside a tab, it becomes the entire experience.

And the craziest part?

Google hasn’t even joined the fight yet.

This isn’t a feature war.

It’s about who owns the starting point of your digital life.

Who controls your attention, your queries, your data.

When the browser becomes AI-native,
the OS doesn’t matter.

Apps don’t matter.

Even search starts to look very different.

So yes, Sam Altman is trying to kill Google.
Not by competing with it.

By replacing where it lives.

When this war ends,

will we still “Google it”

or will we just “Ask ChatGPT”?

What do you think?

AI coding benchmarks are the biggest illusion in tech right now ‼️

I spent last weekend doing something nerdy.

Gave the same messy function to Claude Sonnet 4.5, GPT-5, Gemini 2.0 Pro, and GitHub Copilot.

Same prompt: “Refactor this to be production-ready.”

Now, if you've been following benchmarks, you know Claude Sonnet 4.5 is crushing it at 77.2% on SWE-bench. On paper, it’s the smartest AI coder out there.

But here’s what actually happened 👇
- Copilot surprised me the most. It gave me code that just worked - clean, practical, production-ready. No overthinking, no fluff. I could have shipped it instantly.
Result: https://dub.link/B18c5fx

- Claude Sonnet 4.5 built me an architectural masterpiece - custom error classes, helper functions, neat async/await, and JSDoc comments. Beautiful, but for a simple refactor, it felt like overkill.
Result: https://dub.link/Sthl9OQ

- Gemini 2.0 Pro turned into a mentor - numbered comments, usage examples, and explanations for every choice. Great if you’re learning, but slower if you just need code to ship.
Result: https://dub.link/nyOWmnE

- GPT-5 played it safe - defaulted to TypeScript, added type checks, and returned nulls instead of throwing. Solid, but sometimes too defensive for production needs.
Result: https://dub.link/llr5SDz

And that’s when it clicked for me.

At this level, they can all solve the problem. The real difference is judgment.

How they handle errors. Whether they optimize for safety, speed, or clarity. Whether they’re opinionated or neutral.

Benchmarks will tell you who can solve problems. But production code is about taste, trade-offs, and context.

So maybe we’re asking the wrong question. Instead of “Which AI is the best coder?”

Ask: “Which AI codes the way I think?”

Because that answer will change for every developer, every team, every project.
I run small experiments like this every week 🔬

If you want the full play-by-play (and results I don’t always share here), you’ll find them in my newsletter: https://lnkd.in/gDEUN_Tz

We’ve been on the hunt for an analyst and already interviewed close to 50 candidates.

Honestly, I’m worried about the state of data analytics talent today.

Most people have zero business understanding.

They’re great at hard skills like writing SQL or building dashboards.

They can follow instructions. But that’s exactly what AI can already do on its own.

The real differentiator is not technical execution.

The only skill that truly matters now is the ability to think.

The idea that AI will create new jobs is 100% crap 🤐

That’s not me saying but former Chief Business Officer at Google.

And he’s not just warning about junior coders or factory workers.

He’s saying even CEOs are at risk.

On the Diary of a CEO podcast, Mo shared how he and two engineers built his AI startup, Emma love

In the past, that same project would have taken 350 developers.

With AI, it took 3 people.

Let that sink in.

If AI can collapse 347 roles in one go,

what happens when it starts doing the same to senior managers, strategists, and leadership teams?

We’ve all heard the comforting line:

“Yes, AI will automate some jobs… but it will also create new ones.”

Mo calls that 100% false.

And the numbers seem to back him up.

IBM says 40% of the global workforce will need reskilling within 3 years.

Goldman Sachs predicts 300 million jobs worldwide could be replaced.

Across most industries, jobs aren’t being created. They’re being collapsed.

But here’s the twist.

This shift doesn’t just remove power. It redistributes it.

Not to titles. Not to headcount.

But to whoever knows how to use AI best.

One sharp operator with AI can now outperform an entire team.

Which means the next unicorn founder…

The next disruptor…

The next CEO…

Won’t be the one with the biggest team.

It will be the one who knows how to scale themselves with AI.

So maybe the real question isn’t “Will AI take my job?”

It’s “Will someone who knows AI better than me take it first?”

What do you think harsh truth or unnecessary fear?
